channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Her cancer diagnosis made motherhood both harder and more sweet
item.description: As cancer rates rise among people under 50, more and more parents are facing the heightened emotions and challenging logistics of raising kids while going through treatment.
item.content:encoded:
As cancer rates rise among people under 50, more and more parents are facing the heightened emotions and challenging logistics of raising kids while going through treatment.

(Image credit: Caleb Alvarado for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Yuki Noguchi

item.title: Measles remains a danger to health even years after an infection
item.description: The measles outbreak in Texas and New Mexico is now close to 300 cases. Most are unvaccinated children. People usually recover, but doctors are stressing how dangerous and long-lasting it can be.
item.content:encoded:
The measles outbreak in Texas and New Mexico is now close to 300 cases. Most are unvaccinated children. People usually recover, but doctors are stressing how dangerous and long-lasting it can be.

(Image credit: jure)
item.dc:creator: Maria Godoy

item.title: Deadly storms hit multiple southern states. And, hundreds of Venezuelans deported
item.description: Residents are assessing damage from severe weather that hit multiple U.S. states over the weekend. And, hundreds of people accused of being in a Venezuelan gang have been deported.
item.content:encoded:
Residents are assessing damage from severe weather that hit multiple U.S. states over the weekend. And, hundreds of people accused of being in a Venezuelan gang have been deported.

(Image credit: Jeff Roberson)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Researchers are rushing to build AI-powered robots. But will they work?
item.description: Artificial intelligence has revolutionized the virtual world. But reality bytes.
item.content:encoded:
Artificial intelligence has revolutionized the virtual world. But reality bytes.

(Image credit: Moo Jin Kim/Stanford University)
item.dc:creator: Geoff Brumfiel

item.title: Peruvian farmer goes head to head with German energy giant in climate test case
item.description: A Peruvian farmer is going head to head with German energy giant in a climate law test case.
item.content:encoded:
A Peruvian farmer is going head to head with German energy giant in a climate law test case.

(Image credit: Martin Mejia)
item.dc:creator: Simeon Tegel

item.title: How Alabama students went from last place to rising stars in math
item.description: Alabama is the only state where 4th-grade math scores are higher now than they were in 2019, before the pandemic. This is the story of how the state pulled it off.
item.content:encoded:
Alabama is the only state where 4th-grade math scores are higher now than they were in 2019, before the pandemic. This is the story of how the state pulled it off.

(Image credit: Charity Rachelle for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Cory Turner

item.title: Wholesale egg prices are going down. How soon will it affect your grocery bill?
item.description: Economists say the sharp decline in wholesale egg prices is a positive sign, with some anticipating lower prices at grocery stores in a few weeks.
item.content:encoded:
Economists say the sharp decline in wholesale egg prices is a positive sign, with some anticipating lower prices at grocery stores in a few weeks.

(Image credit: Scott Olson)
item.dc:creator: Juliana Kim

item.title: Here are 4 ways parents can help their teens be smart with screen time
item.description: With teens, it doesn't help to just say no to screen time. Instead, experts suggest teaching them to be smarter viewers of content, and learn to recognize how influencers and algorithms can manipulate them.
item.content:encoded:
With teens, it doesn't help to just say no to screen time. Instead, experts suggest teaching them to be smarter viewers of content, and learn to recognize how influencers and algorithms can manipulate them.

(Image credit: Daniel de la Hoz)
item.dc:creator: Katia Riddle

item.title: 2 separate cases place the immigration lens on Boston
item.description: Two legal immigrants who flew into Boston Logan International Airport have been denied re-entry into the United States after traveling abroad. One was deported in apparent defiance of a judicial order.
item.content:encoded:
Two legal immigrants who flew into Boston Logan International Airport have been denied re-entry into the United States after traveling abroad. One was deported in apparent defiance of a judicial order.

(Image credit: Joseph Prezioso)
item.dc:creator: Tovia Smith

item.title: A Tesla protester targeted by Elon Musk speaks out: 'I have to protect myself'
item.description: "When one of the most powerful, if not the most powerful person in the world is saying you've committed a crime, it doesn't matter what the truth is," says Valerie Costa, an anti-Tesla protester.
item.content:encoded:
"When one of the most powerful, if not the most powerful person in the world is saying you've committed a crime, it doesn't matter what the truth is," says Valerie Costa, an anti-Tesla protester.

(Image credit: Rodrique Ngowi)
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn
